content.webTitle: Lord Tebbit’s test for migrants: who did your grandfather fight for in the war?

fields.headline: Lord Tebbit’s test for migrants: who did your grandfather fight for in the war?
fields.bodyText: Lord Tebbit was once a harsh critic of mass immigration, but the former Conservative party chairman’s latest test as to who should be allowed to enter the country would open the door to most of Europe, including Russia. Mexicans and Brazilians too, would be welcome under his new regime. The Tory party grandee once attracted controversy for his “cricket test” – in which he said that the loyalty of British Asians could be measured by who they supported in international cricket matches. Now, he has told BBC Newsnight, would-be UK citizens should be asked which side their fathers or grandfathers fought for during the second world war. “One test I would use is to ask them on which side their fathers or grandfathers or whatever fought in the second world war,” Tebbit said. “And so you’ll find that the Poles and the Czechs and the Slovaks were all on the right side. And so that’s a pretty good test isn’t it? Perhaps we’ll even manage to teach them to play cricket gradually over the years.” Poles and Czechs aren’t the only ones who would be welcome, however. The allied powers during the war also included the United Sates, the former Soviet Union, Brazil, Mexico, France, Yugoslavia, Greece, Norway, Holland, Belgium, Denmark and South Africa. And that’s not including the UK’s former colony of India (then including what is now Pakistan and Bangladesh) which sent hundreds of thousands of troops. The status of Italians and Romanians, whose home nations switched sides from the Axis to Allied powers in 1943 and 1944 is unclear. Tebbit, 83, the former MP for Chingford, made his cricket test remarks in 1990 in an interview with the Los Angeles Times. He argued that immigrants and their children could not be considered truly loyal to Britain if they supported the cricket team of their country of origin. “A large proportion of Britain’s Asian population fail to pass the cricket test,” he said. “Which side do they cheer for? It’s an interesting test. Are you still harking back to where you came from or where you are?” Since then he has come out in support of the national Asian cricket awards, held at Lord’s in October, saying that a new generation of Asian cricketers has helped Britons with Asian heritage rally around the England side. “In recent years, British Asian players have again given us some of that swashbuckling style of play which the crowds are willing to pay to watch,” he said. “Not only that, but it encourages the generations of British-born Asians to feel part of the nation – and those of long British ancestry to welcome them into our team.” Tebbit was responding to David Cameron’s big immigration speech in which the prime minister stepped back from demanding caps on EU migrants. “I don’t think what David Cameron said today is going to solve our problems because he has to get the agreement of the other 27 heads of government in order to put most of the things which he proposed into action,” he said. “I don’t think we’re going to get net immigration down to the 100,000 mark, which was the promise he made. We’re simply going the wrong way.”
